Vietnam: Battle of the Huế Imperial City. Hàm Nghi leads resistance.
Emperor Đồng Khánh (1885–1889) became ruler of Vietnam.
USA: Grover Cleveland is inaugurated as President.
Tanzania: The German government announces its intention to establish a protectorate in East Africa.
The German East Africa Company is formed by Karl Peters to govern German East Africa.
Taiwan: Keelung Campaign: The French evacuate from Jilong
Singapore: Gan Eng Seng School was established at Telok Ayer Street
Serbia: The Serbo-Bulgarian War results in the country's humiliation following the Unification of Bulgaria increasing hostility toward the House of Obrenović.
Rwanda: The German East Africa Company is formed by Karl Peters to govern German East Africa.
Philippine: Emilio Molíns becomes acting Governor-General (1885). (First Term)
Emilio Terrero y Perinat appointed Governor-General (1885–1888)
Nepal: Ranoddip Singh Rana assassinated; Bir Shamser Rana becomes prime minister
Malta: (Otto Settembre) is recommended as a national holiday, commemorating the victory of the Knights and the Maltese over the Ottoman Empire in the Siege of Malta (1565).
Haiti: Haitian writer Anténor Firmin publishes the book De l'Égalité des Races Humaines, which proclaims the equality of the races
Canada: Several hundred Catholic Francophone Métis led by Louis Riel and supported by Cree fighters mount the North-West Rebellion and establish the Provisional Government of Saskatchewan. Riel is captured at the Battle of Batoche (9–12 May), tried for treason, and hung on 16 November 1885. Francophones bitterly denounce the sentence and Canada becomes deeply polarized along ethno-religious lines.
The transcontinental Canadian Pacific Railway, then the longest in the world, is completed.
Burma: Third Anglo-Burmese War; end of Burmese monarchy
Brazil: Sexagenarian Law, or Saraiva-Cotegipe Law, which frees slaves over the age of 60.
Bhutan: Ugyen Wangchuck, penlop (governor) of Trongsa, puts down civil unrest across Bhutan, consolidates power, and cultivates closer ties with British India.
Barbados: Moves to Confederate isle with the Windward Islands is abandoned, the capital of the Windward Islands shifts to St. George, Grenada; and the island restores self-government as before.
